0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Allergy to penicillin - Female gonococcal pelvic inflammatory disease: 500 mg IV every 6 hr for 3 days, followed by oral administration of 250 mg erythromycin stearate or base every 6 hr OR 500 mg erythromycin base ORALLY every 12 hr OR 333 mg erythromycin base ORALLY every 8 hr for 7 days
  • Bartonellosis - HIV infection: (bacillary angiomatosis, peliosis hepatis, bacteremia, osteomyelitis) 500 mg IV 4 times daily for at least 3 months
  • Diphtheria, adjunct to antitoxin; Adjunct: 15 to 20 mg/kg/day IV in divided doses; MAX 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Erythrasma: 15 to 20 mg/kg/day IV in divided doses; MAX 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue (Mild to Moderate), Caused by S. pyogenes or S. aureus: 15 to 20 mg/kg/day IV in divided doses; MAX 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Legionnaires disease: 1 to 4 g IV daily in divided doses
  • Respiratory tract infection: 15 to 20 mg/kg/day IV in divided doses (dosing intervals not to exceed every 6 hours); MAX 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Allergy to penicillin - Female gonococcal pelvic inflammatory disease: 500 mg IV every 6 hr for 3 days, followed by oral administration of 250 mg erythromycin stearate or base every 6 hr OR 500 mg erythromycin base ORALLY every 12 hr OR 333 mg erythromycin base ORALLY every 8 hr for 7 days
  • Bartonellosis - HIV infection: (cutaneous bacillary angiomatosis) 15 to 50 mg/kg/day (MAX 2 g/day) IV divided into 4 doses/day for 3 months
  • Diphtheria, adjunct to antitoxin; Adjunct: 15 to 20 mg/kg/day IV in divided doses; MAX 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Erythrasma: 15 to 20 mg/kg/day IV in divided doses; MAX 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue (Mild to Moderate), Caused by S. pyogenes or S. aureus: 15 to 20 mg/kg/day IV in divided doses; MAX 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Respiratory tract infection: 15 to 20 mg/kg/day IV in divided doses (dosing intervals not to exceed every 6 hours); MAX 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Respiratory tract infection: (community acquired pneumonia; older than 3 months of age) 20 mg/kg/day IV divided every 6 hours (guideline dosing)

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Allergy to penicillin - Female gonococcal pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Diphtheria, adjunct to antitoxin; Adjunct
  • Erythrasma
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue (Mild to Moderate), Caused by S. pyogenes or S. aureus
  • Legionnaires disease
  • Respiratory tract infection
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Bartonellosis - HIV infection
  • Gastroparesis syndrome

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• concomitant use with astemizole or terfenadine
  • hypersensitivity to erythromycin products

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• prolonged QT intervals, cardiac arrest, torsades de pointes and other ventricular arrhythmias have been reported
  • diarrhea (Clostridium difficile associated), ranging in severity from mild diarrhea to fatal colitis, has been reported; discontinuation may be necessary
  • elderly patients; increased risk for hearing loss with higher doses, torsades de pointes arrhythmias, increased oral anticoagulant effects
  • hepatic dysfunction, with or without jaundice, has been reported
  • hepatic impairment; increased exposure
  • myasthenia gravis patients; weakness aggravated
  • superinfection has been reported; discontinue use if suspected

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• Erythromycin: AAP: Maternal medication usually compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Erythromycin: WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Erythromycin: Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Irritation symptom, Venous (occasional)
  • Dermatologic:Urticaria
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Prolonged QT interval (rare), Ventricular tachycardia (rare)
  • Dermatologic:Erythema multiforme, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, Toxic epidermal necrolysis (rare)
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis
  • Otic:Hearing loss, Patients with renal insufficiency (high doses)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Erythromycin lactobionate is a macrolide antibiotic acts by binding to 50 S ribosomal subunits of susceptible pathogens.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    for IV use only
  • Intravenous
    • (vials) reconstitute only with Sterile Water for Injection, USP to a concentration of 50 mg/mL; do not use diluents containing preservatives or inorganic salts
    • (continuous infusion) dilute the reconstituted solution with NS or LR to a concentration of 1 mg/mL and use within 8 hours
    • (intermittent infusion) dilute the reconstituted solution with no less than 100 mL of NS or LR to a concentration of 1 to 5 mg/mL and infuse over 20 to 60 minutes at intervals not greater than every 6 hours; use within 8 hours of preparation
    • (infusion) may also dilute reconstituted solution with D5W, D5WLR, or D5NS provided they are buffered by addition of 1 mL of Neut(R) (4% sodium bicarbonate) per 100 mL of solution
    • continuous (preferable) or intermittent IV infusion only; do not use IV push
    • (ADD-vantage vials) add the 500 mg vial to 100 mL of NS or D5W in the ADD-vantage flexible diluent container for a concentration of 5 mg/mL and use within 8 hours of preparation
    • (ADD-vantage vials) add the 1 g vial to 250 mL of NS or D5W in the ADD-vantage flexible diluent container for a concentration of 4 mg/mL and use within 2 hours of preparation

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• symptomatic improvement
  • hepatic function
  • hearing exam (hearing loss, especially with high doses and renal or hepatic insufficiency)

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
Erythrocin Lactobionate
Intravenous Powder for Solution: 1 GM, 500 MG

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
MACROLIDE ANTIBIOTICS
OVERDOSE: Significant toxicity following acute overdose is uncommon. N/V, abdominal pain may occur. ADVERSE EFFECTS: N/V, abdominal pain, diarrhea most common. Cholestasis, sensorineural hearing loss, thrombophlebitis (IV administration), ventricular dysrhythmias/QT prolongation (IV administration) are less common.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
MACROLIDE ANTIBIOTICS
  • Decontamination: Activated charcoal, gastric lavage.
  • Support: Therapy as indicated.
  • Abdominal discomfort: Food, milk or an antacid may be given; most effects reverse with drug cessation
  • Monitoring of patient: Baseline ECG, cardiac monitoring as indicated. Renal and hepatic function as indicated.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
MACROLIDE ANTIBIOTICS
In general, the macrolide antibiotics are of a low order toxicity.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patients to report signs/symptoms ototoxicity, especially elderly patients on high-dose regimens or with renal insufficiency.
  • Patients with a history of myasthenia gravis should report signs/symptoms of disease exacerbation during therapy.
  • Patient should avoid concomitant use of terfenadine or astemizole.
